content:
Full acceptance, not wrap-span">mere wrap-span">tolerance, is a better goal for open societies, says Denzel wrap-span">Chung

This essay is the winner of The Economist ’s Open Future essay competition in the wrap-span">category of Open Borders, responding to the question: “Does immigration strengthen or wrap-span">undermine wrap-span">tolerance?” The winner is Denzel wrap-span">Chung, 18 years old, from New Zealand. 

*    *    *

Moving from Malaysia to New Zealand, our family has seen it all. We have seen a brave new world of wrap-span">inclusive wrap-span">multiculturalism. We saw wrap-span">genuine efforts made to start understanding and embracing the unique culture we brought with us, just as we made our own efforts to understand and embrace the culture of our new neighbours.

We have learned (wrap-span">albeit wrap-span">wrap-span">reluctantly) to put Marmite on wrap-span">toast as well as in rice congee. They have learned (wrap-span">albeit wrap-span">wrap-span">reluctantly) to use peanuts and wrap-span">spices in wrap-span">satay wrap-span">sauce, instead of peanut butter and cream. We have learned to kick back on Waitangi Day or Queen’s Birthday Weekend and get to know New Zealand’s rich Māori and Pakeha history, while they have learned about the wrap-span">cacophonous, wrap-span">multicultural wrap-span">Malaysian wrap-span">feasts of Chinese New Year, Hari Raya Aidilfitri and Deepavali.

We have also seen a wrap-span">darker wrap-span">underbelly, the seething wrap-span">resentment and wrap-span">wrap-span">implicit wrap-span">discrimination wrap-span">occasionally wrap-span">boiling over into wrap-span">outright wrap-span">racism (that wrap-span">dreaded “r-word,” so wrap-span">potent and so feared, and so much more wrap-span">convenient to brush off and sweep under the wrap-span">carpet).

We saw as my parents, well-paid professionals in Malaysia, wrap-span">trudged through a wrap-span">variety of wrap-span">menial jobs, struggling to apply for minimum-wage work; and not for a lack of wrap-span">qualifications, experience or even English-language ability. We wrap-span">cringed as wrap-span">apoplectic politicians attacked yet another farm, factory or wrap-span">residential home being sold to “the Chinese”; culminating in the then-opposition Labour Party claiming an overseas wrap-span">hijacking of our housing market, based on the fact that 39.5% of house purchasers in wrap-span">Auckland had “Chinese-sounding names”. We wrap-span">groaned as we went through the usual wrap-span">baptism of fire for any new immigrant, the cocked-eyebrow and wrap-span">puzzled look as you struggle to get your words across, the wrap-span">constant sniggers and cries of “sorry, I didn’t get that,” little wrap-span">snipes at the wrap-span">wrap-span">outwardly different and the wrap-span">distinctive.

New Zealand has been a land of immigrants throughout its modern history, and, like the rest of the world, has experienced significant growth in immigration in the last several decades. This was usually thought to have been driven as much by a wrap-span">liberalisation of attitudes as much as of borders and air travel. How, then, can immigration serve both to strengthen wrap-span">tolerance and wrap-span">seemingly wrap-span">undermine it? This wrap-span">seemingly wrap-span">hypocritical wrap-span">juxtaposition becomes clearer when the meaning of the word “wrap-span">tolerance” is made clearer.

Why the word “wrap-span">Tolerance” was chosen to wrap-span">hearken a new age of wrap-span">enlightened wrap-span">multiculturalism is forever a wrap-span">mystery to me. “wrap-span">Tolerance” wrap-span">implies a wrap-span">wrap-span">reluctant, begrudging acceptance, and indeed it is defined as an ability to bear with something one disagrees with, or dislikes, without wrap-span">interference. If this is wrap-span">Tolerance, immigration has certainly strengthened it. Through immigration, there is broad wrap-span">consensus across wide wrap-span">swathes of society that immigrants are actually extremely useful, wrap-span">vital to prevent wrap-span">shortages of skilled professionals as well as being a wrap-span">potent engine of economic growth. For instance, for the last few years, New Zealand’s economy, generally subject to the swings and wrap-span">roundabouts of commodity prices and tourist numbers, has been growing wrap-span">consistently, driven almost wrap-span">exclusively by immigration and its flow-on effects.

The 2017 wrap-span">Perceptions of Asia survey, carried out by the Asia New Zealand wrap-span">Foundation, found that the vast majority of New Zealanders saw Asian tourism, investment and economic growth as being positive to New Zealand’s future. In a similar wrap-span">vein, the 2017 European Social Survey found that a skilled professional or a student with good grades could overcome the “wrap-span">ethnic wrap-span">penalty” of wrap-span">discrimination generally applied to non-European, non-Christian migrants, so strongly was individual wrap-span">approval of migrants tied to their relative skills or talents.

While wrap-span">respondents would wrap-span">consistently favour wrap-span">unskilled labourers from Europe over those from elsewhere, an individual would wrap-span">theoretically view any skilled professional immigrant, whether from Ireland, India or the wrap-span">Ivory wrap-span">Coast, equally highly. However, just because the presence of an immigrant is wrap-span">tolerated and their skills wrap-span">appreciated does not necessarily mean that they are welcomed, or even accepted, and the wrap-span">endless wrap-span">apocryphal tales of wrap-span">woe circulated among new migrants can be backed up by evidence of an attitude towards immigration that can wrap-span">verge on wrap-span">hostility.

wrap-span">Notably, attitudes towards the different cultures and ways of life immigrants bring with them are significantly wrap-span">cooler than attitudes towards immigration in general. Recent research in Australia, for instance, found almost half of wrap-span">respondents agreeing that people from minority groups should behave more like mainstream Australians and that “Australia is weakened by people of different wrap-span">ethnic origins sticking to their old ways”.  

The 2017 European Social Survey found much more positive attitudes towards migrants of the same race or wrap-span">ethnic group, such as other Europeans, as well as agreement in the wrap-span">importance of immigrants committing to their host country’s “way of life”. The Asia New Zealand wrap-span">Foundation’s survey found that less than half of wrap-span">respondents actually believed Asian immigration, or Asian cultures and traditions, would be positive for New Zealand’s future, notwithstanding the fact that large majorities of wrap-span">respondents saw tourism and investment from Asia as being positive for New Zealand’s future.

These case studies show most clearly the danger of accepting a wrap-span">mere “wrap-span">tolerance” of immigrants. This begrudging acceptance may lead to wrap-span">wrap-span">outward harmony, but hides wrap-span">toxic wrap-span">viewpoints that can significantly wrap-span">strain wrap-span">interwrap-span">racial relations further down the track.  Yes, a wrap-span">tolerance of immigrants wrap-span">indicates that they are broadly viewed as useful, whether for driving demand, mitigating skill wrap-span">shortages or providing investment capital and wrap-span">empirical evidence (as shown above) tends to support this.

However a wrap-span">tolerance of immigrants also wrap-span">indicates, at best, an wrap-span">apathetic wrap-span">disregard for them, and at worst, an active wrap-span">hostility kept under wraps swrap-span">imply because they are wrap-span">perceived as necessary. wrap-span">Empirically, wrap-span">negative views of immigrant cultures and traditions seem to wrap-span">persist, as does a view that immigrants should behave more like native-born “locals,” that they wrap-span">conform more tightly to the attitudes of the majority. Like a wrap-span">liberal democracy trading with an wrap-span">ideological wrap-span">foe, an wrap-span">wrap-span">outward relationship that seems wrap-span">cooperative, or even wrap-span">congenial, wrap-span">conceals a wrap-span">demonstrable, marked wrap-span">hostility, a wrap-span">fundamental, wrap-span">unresolved wrap-span">mismatch of wrap-span">mutually-misunderstood cultures and attitudes. 

The current wrap-span">viewpoint of strengthening “wrap-span">tolerance” towards immigration wrap-span">forestalls efforts to connect with immigrants, engage with them or learn more about their culture and wrap-span">heritage. It dehumanises immigrants, promoting a view of them as wrap-span">merely a “necessary evil”. It reduces them to the role of a machine to do what needs to be done, a machine that should get on with its job quietly, out of sight and with wrap-span">minimal wrap-span">fuss. Despite 59% of New Zealanders in the Asia New Zealand wrap-span">Foundation survey of 2018 admitting little involvement with Asian people or cultures, some of the primary reasons that some wrap-span">respondents felt “less warm” towards them was a wrap-span">cited “wrap-span">influx” of Asians, or their wrap-span">tendency to “stick to their own,” rather than “wrap-span">integrate”. 

When immigrants are reduced to the status of a wrap-span">mere machine, it becomes wrap-span">terrifyingly easy to wrap-span">dispense with them or wrap-span">dismiss them if circumstances render it necessary. Eventually, for the media and politicians of all wrap-span">stripes to wrap-span">alternately celebrate and wrap-span">slander them as the tides of national opinion wrap-span">ebb and flow becomes not so much wrap-span">heartlessness as wrap-span">mere wrap-span">pragmatism.

Of course, immigration strengthens wrap-span">tolerance. Immigration is wrap-span">vital to cover wrap-span">deficits of skilled workers and manual labourers, as well as deliver economic growth. Even wrap-span">racial wrap-span">supremacists and wrap-span">bigots wrap-span">recognise that immigrants can be necessary to the wrap-span">proper functioning of a nation. However wrap-span">tolerance is not the same as acceptance, and just because immigrants are able to live relatively peacefully in a country does not necessarily wrap-span">indicate a full-throated agreement to their presence, never mind their culture or their way of life.

Just as the investment-wrap-span">starved wrap-span">apartheid regime of South Africa welcomed wealthy Japanese as “wrap-span">honorary whites,” a wrap-span">superficial wrap-span">recognition of immigrants as wrap-span">economically necessary exists across the world today. Though wrap-span">external peace is present, this wrap-span">ultimately does as little to change the broader national attitude around immigrants as accepting the Japanese did for wrap-span">multiculturalism in South Africa. A broader wrap-span">sentiment of wrap-span">resentment towards new arrivals continues below the surface, with terrible wrap-span">consequences both for host citizens and the immigrants in their adopted home.

To make the shift requires less a change in policy or wrap-span">legislation as a change in attitude. It requires people to move past the traditional wrap-span">viewpoint of seeing immigrants as a necessary evil, as wrap-span">mere machines to make economic wrap-span">indicators more wrap-span">impressive or to sit in offices and hospitals because no one else wants to.

We should look past just celebrating immigrants’ bank balances and university degrees, to also see their unique cultures, wrap-span">perspectives and ways of life; if not always to be celebrated, to at least be understood in wrap-span">perspective. We must no longer swrap-span">imply stand for "wrap-span">tolerance" of immigrants, but we must stand for accepting, respecting and understanding them too.

______

Denzel wrap-span">Chung is a student in health sciences at the University of Otago in wrap-span">Dunedin, New Zealand.
